turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about I Have a Dream.
turn.1: What was the reception to Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream"?
turn.2: Marquis Childs of "The Washington Post" wrote that King's speech "rose above mere oratory".
turn.3: What did others say about it?
turn.4: An article in the "Los Angeles Times" commented that the "matchless eloquence" displayed by King—"a supreme orator" of "a type so rare as almost to be forgotten in our age"—put to shame the advocates of segregation by inspiring the "conscience of America" with the justice of the civil-rights cause.
turn.6: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), which viewed King and his allies for racial justice as subversive, also noticed the speech.
turn.7: What did they do after the speech?
turn.8: This provoked the organization to expand their COINTELPRO operation against the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), and to target King specifically as a major enemy of the United States.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: Two days after King delivered "I Have a Dream", Agent William C. Sullivan, the head of COINTELPRO, wrote a memo about King's growing influence: In the light of King's powerful demagogic speech yesterday he stands head and shoulders above all other Negro leaders put together when it comes to influencing great masses of Negroes.
turn.11: What did he go on to say?
turn.12: We must mark him now, if we have not done so before, as the most dangerous Negro of the future in this Nation from the standpoint of communism, the Negro and national security.
